questions.text: A physiologist is studying blood flow in a network of four parallel blood vessels. The effective resistance of the network of vessels is 4.8 R units. The pressure at the proximal end of the network is 150 mmHg, and the pressure at the distal end is 90 mmHg. What is the total blood flow rate through the network of vessels?

options.label: A
options.text: 8 L/s

options.label: D
options.text: 20 L/s

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Capillaries provide maximum total peripheral resistance

options.label: B
options.text: Arteries contain the most blood volume in the systemic circulation

options.label: C
options.text: Fenestrated capillaries has gaps size ranging from 300-600 nm

options.label: D
options.text: A-V anastomoses found in earlobes have thick, muscular walls

questions.correct_answer: D. A-V anastomoses found in earlobes have thick, muscular walls
questions.explanation:
Blood Vessel Type

Blood Volume

Arteries

  • Carry oxygenated blood away from the heart.
  • Arteries have elastic tissue in their walls, allowing them to stretch and recoil with the pumping of the heart.

8%

Arterioles

  • They are the primary site of resistance to blood flow
  • Contain a high proportion of smooth muscle

1%

Capillaries

  • Tiny vessels with thin walls for the exchange of gases, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissues.

5%

Veins

  • Veins have thinner walls allowing them to distend easily and accommodate larger volumes of blood.
  • Contain venous valves to prevent backflow of blood

54% (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the characteristics of laminar blood flow?

options.label: A
options.text: Laminar blood flow is characterized by chaotic and irregular movements with significant mixing of fluid layers.

options.label: B
options.text: Laminar blood flow occurs at high velocities and low fluid viscosity, leading to smooth and orderly movement.

options.label: C
options.text: Laminar blood flow occurs at low velocities and high fluid viscosity, with fluid particles moving in parallel layers.

options.label: D
options.text: Laminar blood flow is responsible for generating Korotkoff sounds during blood pressure measurement.

questions.correct_answer: C. Laminar blood flow occurs at low velocities and high fluid viscosity, with fluid particles moving in parallel layers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly applies the law of Laplace in cardiovascular physiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Capillaries are prone to rupture due to high wall tension.

options.label: B
options.text: Dilated hearts have to work harder due to increased myocardial tension.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased flow velocity in narrow vessels reduces distending pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: The total energy in a tube or blood vessel remains constant.

questions.correct_answer: B. Dilated hearts have to work harder due to increased myocardial tension.
questions.explanation:
Principle

Definition

Applications

Law of Laplace

The tension in the wall of a cylinder is equal to the product of transmural pressure and radius divided by wall thickness.

T= P.r/ 2w ( T= Tension, P= Transmural pressure, r= Radius, w= Wall thickness)

Capillaries: Low tension in walls due to small radius, resistant to rupture. (Option A)

Dilated Hearts: Increased radius requires more tension, increasing cardiac workload.(Option B)

Bernoulli Principle

The total energy in a tube or blood vessel (kinetic energy + potential energy) remains constant. (Option D)


 

Pressure Measurement: Lower side arm pressure in a T tube due to kinetic energy of flow. Atherosclerotic Plaques: Increased flow velocity in narrow vessels reduces distending pressure, maintaining vessel narrowing. (Option C)

questions.text: A 45-y/o male patient presents with a blood pressure reading of 150/90 mmHg. Which of the following statements about his pulse pressure (PP) and mean arterial pressure (MAP) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Pulse pressure is 40 mmHg, and MAP is 110 mmHg.

options.label: B
options.text: Pulse pressure is 60 mmHg, and MAP is 100 mmHg.

options.label: C
options.text: Pulse pressure is 60 mmHg, and MAP is 110 mmHg.

options.label: D
options.text: Pulse pressure is 40 mmHg, and MAP is 100 mmHg.

questions.correct_answer: C. Pulse pressure is 60 mmHg, and MAP is 110 mmHg.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Pulse Pressure (PP)

Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP)

Definition

Difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure

Average pressure in arteries during one cardiac cycle

Calculation

PP=SBP−DBP

MAP=DBP+1/3(SBP−DBP)

Normal Range

40-60 mmHg

70-100 mmHg

Clinical Significance

Indicates cardiovascular health and heart function

A better indicator of perfusion to vital organs

Implications of High Values

Risk of cardiovascular events

Can indicate a risk of hypertension and organ damage

Implications of Low Values

This may suggest poor heart function

This may indicate poor perfusion of vital organs

questions.text: Which of the following is the fastest acting method of BP regulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Capillary fluid shift

options.label: B
options.text: Baroreceptor reflex

options.label: C
options.text: Renin-angiotensin vasoconstriction

options.label: D
options.text: Renal body fluid mechanism

questions.explanation:
Time Frame

Mechanisms

Functions

Short-term (seconds to minutes)
  • Autonomic nervous system
  • Baroreceptor reflex
  • Central nervous system ischemic response
  • Chemoreceptor mechanism
  • Constrict veins to increase blood flow to the heart
  • Increase heart rate and contractility
  • Constrict peripheral arterioles to elevate BP

Intermediate-term (minutes to hours)
  • Angiotensin mediated vasoconstriction (Option C)
  • Stress relaxation
  • Capillary fluid shift (Option A)
  • Renin triggers angiotensin II, constricting blood vessels and increasing BP
  • Sustained high BP leads to gradual pressure reduction
  • Fluid absorption or loss in capillaries adjusts blood volume and BP

Long-term (days to years)
  • Renal-body fluid mechanism (Option D)
  • Aldosterone influence
  • Regulate salt and water excretion to maintain BP stability
  • Aldosterone promotes salt and water retention when BP is low

Aspect

Details

Mechanism
  • Baroreceptors in carotid sinus and aortic arch detect BP changes
  • Increased BP stretches receptors, sending signals to medulla via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves
  • Medulla inhibits vasoconstrictor center and stimulates vagal parasympathetic center

Actions
  • Vasodilation of blood vessels
  • Decreased heart rate and contraction strength
  • Reduced BP due to lower peripheral resistance and cardiac output

Importance
  • Maintains BP stability during activities like standing
  • Fastest acting (Option B)
  • Tends to reset within 1-2 days for long-term regulation

questions.text: A patient undergoing PCI for myocardial infarction suddenly develops bradycardia, hypotension, and episodes of apnoea.Which of the following reflexes is most likely mediated by chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region?

options.label: A
options.text: Cushing reflex

options.label: B
options.text: Bainbridge reflex

options.label: C
options.text: Bezold-Jarisch reflex

options.label: D
options.text: Baroreceptor reflex

questions.text: A patient with massive blood loss is found to have increased sympathetic nervous system activity, resulting in elevated blood pressure. Which combination of factors primarily triggers the central nervous system (CNS) ischemic response?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoxia and hypercapnia

options.label: B
options.text: Hypoxia and hypocapnia

options.label: C
options.text: Hypoglycemia and hypoxia

options.label: D
options.text: Hypoglycemia and hypercapnia

questions.text: 55-y/o patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with acute exacerbation. ABG shows severe hypoxemia and hypercapnia. How do peripheral chemoreceptors respond to these changes, and its effect on blood pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: Stimulation of chemoreceptors leading to hypertension

options.label: B
options.text: Deactivation of chemoreceptors leading to hypotension

options.label: C
options.text: No response of chemoreceptors leading to hypotension

options.label: D
options.text: Deactivation of chemoreceptors but no response on blood pressure

questions.correct_answer: A. Stimulation of chemoreceptors leading to hypertension

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with acute exacerbation. ABG shows severe hypoxemia and hypercapnia. How do peripheral chemoreceptors respond to these changes, and its effect on blood pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: Stimulation of chemoreceptors leading to hypertension

options.label: B
options.text: Deactivation of chemoreceptors leading to hypotension

options.label: C
options.text: No response of chemoreceptors leading to hypotension

options.label: D
options.text: Deactivation of chemoreceptors but no response on blood pressure

questions.correct_answer: A. Stimulation of chemoreceptors leading to hypertension

questions.text: A 55 y/o man is undergoing a treadmill stress test. Which of the following is true about coronary perfusion?

options.label: A
options.text: Primarily occurs during left ventricle systole

options.label: B
options.text: It is the difference between aortic systolic pressure and diastolic pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Right ventricle perfusion decreases during systole than diastole.

options.label: D
options.text: Regulation of coronary blood flow involves local metabolites

questions.correct_answer: D. Regulation of coronary blood flow involves local metabolites
questions.explanation:
Key points

Explanation

Coronary circulation

Supplies heart muscles

Major coronary arteries

Left and right coronary arteries

Rate of blood flow in myocardium

250ml/minute

Percentage of blood flow in heart

5% of cardiac output

questions.text: Which of the following statements about myocardial muscle tension is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Preload primarily affects the velocity of muscle shortening

options.label: B
options.text: Afterload does not affect the duration of systole

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing preload leads to decreased muscle tension

options.label: D
options.text: The force-velocity relationship in cardiac muscle is inverse and hyperbolic

questions.correct_answer: D. The force-velocity relationship in cardiac muscle is inverse and hyperbolic

questions.text: According to the Monro-Kellie doctrine, which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the intracranial pressure (ICP) homeostasis?

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in cerebrospinal fluid volume can be compensated by a decrease in brain tissue volume

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in blood volume can be offset by a decrease in cerebrospinal fluid volume

options.label: C
options.text: The sum of volumes of brain tissue, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid remains constant

options.label: D
options.text: A significant increase in one intracranial component always leads to a proportional increase in ICP

questions.correct_answer: A. An increase in cerebrospinal fluid volume can be compensated by a decrease in brain tissue volume

questions.text: In a scientific research, large group of non-hypertensive individuals (systolic blood pressures < 120 mm Hg) were studied every 2 years throughout their adult lives. Effects of age and sex on arterial pressure components (systolic and diastolic BP) in the study are given below. Fall of diastolic pressure after the middle age is due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Increase stiffness of arteries

options.label: B
options.text: Decreases stiffness of arteries

options.label: C
options.text: Decrease in contractile force of heart

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease in total peripheral resistance
